items.title: Lady Alisoun’s Margin to the Council
items.body:
To the Twelve of Irenne—
You asked whether Merryen’s wide steps make rebels. I answer: they make citizens who do not stumble. On the river stairs this morning a fishmonger steadied a porter with a turn any knight would envy; no trumpet sounded, and yet the city kept its footing. If drill must exist, let it be the kind that leaves no corpse.
The guild’s road-treaty—this “copy for a copy”—offends merchants who prefer locks. Let them be offended. Locks breed thieves, but shared books breed witnesses. I will not bid the presses silent; I will bid them wise.
As for the Fifth, call it by its true name: Silence. It is not for parades, nor for my household guard. Keep it coded in song and margin. Give the young four voices to sing in the square; let the last be a rest marked only between friends.
If the Empire asks for patents on breath, send them my seal and my laughter.
— Lady Alisoun of Irenne

items.title: Serjeant Waryn’s Letter to His Daughter
items.body:
Edith—
I dreamed the old field again: mud to the knee and orders like hail. Woke standing in the lane, blade in hand that wasn’t there. A boy with a broom asked if I was dancing. I told him I had forgotten how.
A bard named Faelar showed me a turn that leaves both men alive. He said a tune can catch a blade if the foot is honest. I have known honest feet only on long roads.
If I come by Bonona, I will bring ribbons for your hair and a story with no killing in it. Keep your mother’s letter by the hearth; read it when the wind is hard. Tell little Thom that a serjeant once learned to step softer.
— Waryn

items.title: Perkin the Pressboy: Night Ledger (Unsent)
items.body:
Account of Perkin, apprentice to Master Jory the Printer, set down after Compline and before dawn.
— Two formes locked true; the quoins bit like good teeth. I inked with vinegar that isn’t vinegar and laid the sheet by the stove. The letters sweated. Master says that is the sign of living type.
— A merchant came with coin for a forbidden copy. Master said, as always, "You may have a copy if you leave a copy behind." The man left a map with the corners ripped and took away a sermon with the teeth filed. I swept up the filings.
— A woman in velvet (the Lady Alisoun herself? I did not stare) spoke quietly with a guildsman who smelled of rope and rain. They traded a page for a page without touching hands. It was like watching two rivers change beds.
— After midnight a boy from the tannery brought a handbill from Merryen—"Drill at dawn by the river stairs"—and asked if we would strike more. Master said yes, then set his finger on a blank space and said, "Leave a rest there. Silence reads faster than words."
— I set my own letters at last: P-E-R-K-I-N. I hid them in the gutter of a broadsheet so that when a man smooths the fold he will feel my name and not know why.
— The monks came just before cockcrow with a parcel that warmed my palms through the paper. Prior Hubert would not name what was inside. I named it myself: the Fifth, wrapped like a sleeping coal.
I am small, but the press is large. When I pull the bar, the city breathes.
— Perkin

items.title: Prior Hubert’s Confession Regarding the Fifth
items.body:
To the Abbot of St. Eber (for your eye and God’s, not the Chapter’s),
I said we kept the lower stacks dry. I lied. The river kissed the stones last week and the diagrams breathed as the old marginalium warns. Brother Ansel took a gloss to the palm that will not wash; he says it hums to the rhythm of marching and asks to be set to copying until the music passes. I set him instead to ringing the small bell until his hand remembers other measures.
The city wants its steps in straight lines. Merryen and his kind use ink like trumpets; I use it like water on a hot blade—hiss, cool, temper. The guild’s rule of reciprocity is a mercy disguised as a nuisance; the Empire will call it sedition because sedition is easier to spell than mercy.
As for the Fifth, I have written it in rests and given it to a boy who cannot yet read but knows when a room changes breath. If this is heresy, then I prefer this heresy to any tidy obedience.
When I was young I believed Stone was God’s voice; now I know God has many registers. Let us keep the loud ones for feast days and the quiet for saving lives.
I commend my untruths to your judgment.
— Prior Hubert

items.title: Deposition of Serjeant Waryn Before the Red Canal Guild
items.body:
Taken down by Guild-scribe Marla on the fourth day of April, in the hall by the red stairs.
Question: "State your trade."
Answer: "Soldiering, until I learned a better one."
He stood crooked, as men do who have taught their bones to remember blows. He named three dukes he’d served and none he’d loved. When asked what turned him from pay, he said a stowaway with a lute drew a five-pointed star on a ship’s deck and made tired hands move like craftsmen. "I thought then," he said, "that measure could unteach killing."
He described the Fifth as you would describe a winter that lives under the floorboards. "It is not a note," he said, "but the hush that keeps notes from becoming orders. You can hear it when boys start whispering instead of shouting."
Of Merryen he spoke without hatred. "He wants a parade that does not end," Waryn said. "Parades end in walls. The road has no walls."
He told of a levy drilled to a hymn until the hymn grew teeth. He stepped a simple turn on the hall’s stones and showed how a man can give a stranger his life back with a palm instead of a point. Two journeymen tried the turn and failed twice, then laughed when they caught it. The room loosened.
Asked what he wanted in payment for his testimony, he said: "Paper for the printer’s boy, and a rope for the canal men that won’t rot, and a ribbon for my Edith. If you owe me more than that, pay it forward in rests."
— Attested, Marla of Bonona

items.title: The Covenant of the Bridge at Bonona
items.body:
On the twentieth day of April the river ran low enough to bare the old stones. There, at dusk, four hands set seals to a page that was more promise than law.
Lady Alisoun of Irenne came in plain wool, her ring turned inward. Prior Hubert brought a parchment whose back was a child’s practice hand. Serjeant Waryn leaned on the rail and counted the boards between lanterns. Faelar Brighton tuned his lute until the bridge itself seemed to listen.
The Covenant spoke first of copies: that any man or woman may take a page of the Art if they leave a page of equal weight—witness, correction, map, song, mercy done and written down. Second, it named the Four Voices as public: Wind for teaching, Water for trade, Stone for record, Flame for warning. Third, it bound the Fifth—Silence—to margins and music, to be taught as rest and never as march.
"We will not mint soldiers," said Alisoun, "but neighbors." Hubert added, "Where we cannot write safely, we will breathe wisely." Waryn swore a soldier’s oath in reverse: "I will step first for life." Faelar wrote a bar of music on the bottom edge, a measure that breaks if you try to march to it.
A boy in the shadows—Perkin—held the ink. A canal man tied the covenant to the under-beam with tarred thread. Someone, years from now, will find it when the river forgets itself again.
There were no trumpets. The city did not change at once. But a press pulled smoother that night; a monk slept without hearing drums; a veteran woke with both hands open.
At the end Faelar said softly, "A copy for a copy," and Alisoun answered, "And a rest for a life."
— Witnessed at the Red Bridge, Bonona

items.title: Lady Ysabet to Her Steward, On Proper Audiences
items.body:
Steward Dorant—
On market days admit petitioners by craft, not rank. The printers first; their ink keeps better order than swords. If Master Merryen sends another broadside to be posted on my gates, paste it at the river stairs instead where the lads already practice their measure.
—Ysabet of Irenne

items.title: Entry from the Irenne Steward’s Ledger
items.body: Item: Two sacks coarse meal to the riverside yard for drills (by Lady’s order). Item: Chalk to the fencing-master for lines. Item: Sand to cover pride when boys fall.

items.title: Court Herald’s Courtyard Note
items.body: Trumpets to be soft when the Lady watches the drills from the gallery; hard brass makes the steps into a march. The fencing-man says the point is grace, not thunder.

items.title: Footman Benit’s Errand Slip
items.body: From the kitchens to the practice yard: three jugs water, one pot salve, a loaf. The Lady says feed the boys that learn to step; hungry lads learn to shove.

items.title: From the Irenne Children’s Copybook
items.body: Copy: “Measure is kindness.” Copy again: “Noise is not courage.” The little one asked if the letters could dance. I said yes, but only in the margins.

items.title: Tomalin the Devil to Mira at the Press
items.body:
M—
Bought vinegar (ink), bread (bread), and a sack for formes that looks like flour (it is flour). The guard at East Gate asked why I carry an alphabet. I said to feed a city.
—T.

items.title: Mira the Typesetter’s Lament
items.body: Lost: three ‘e’s and a patient temper. Found: a line that sings if you space it gentle. The bard came by and said letters are steps; I told him steps are letters for feet.

items.title: Apprentice to His Sister, On Ink
items.body:
Ses,
My fingers blacken faster than the sun sets. Master says a clean hand makes a dull page. He keeps a lute under the counter and plays when the formes dry.
—Joren

items.title: Runner Jani’s Canal Route Notes
items.body: From press to quay: three bridges, one watch post (kind), two dogs (unkind). Safer to hum than to run. Men step aside if you keep a measure.

items.title: Brother Ansel’s Cellar Tasks
items.body: Turn the barrels. Wipe the damp off the bindings. Do not sing in the lower stacks; the stone keeps time and we ought not teach it.

items.title: Brother Ansel to the Prior, On Visitors
items.body:
Father—
A gentleman in city boots asked to see the diagrams. I showed him the herb garden instead. He left with thyme and less pride. A mercy.
—A.

items.title: Novice Piero’s Penance Lines
items.body: I will leave rests between my words. I will leave rests between my deeds. I will not teach a door to march.

items.title: From the Abbey Gate-Book
items.body: Visitors: a tinker, a widow, two boys with a wooden sword (confiscated, returned with blessing), a bard with quiet eyes (admitted to the garden, not the library).

items.title: Veteran Joryn to a Young Recruit
items.body:
Boy—
Keep your feet like you keep your tongue: still unless asked. If a man shouts himself brave, loan him your silence; he’ll spend it quick and go home early.
—J. Veld

items.title: Receipt for Salve and Bandage
items.body: Paid by H. Cutter, late of the Pike: one jar salve, one roll linen, one song taught to the apothecary’s boy (worth more than coin, said he).

items.title: Alard the Tanner’s Street Song
items.body:
Step wide, step kind,
Leave thunder to the drumline.
If your heel finds time,
Your heart will, in turn.

items.title: Bosun Rell’s Dockside List
items.body: Rope, tar, biscuit, and chalk (for the lads who fancy drawing stars on deck). Captain says leave it; they fight neater with it underfoot.

items.title: From the Room Book at the Crescent Hearth
items.body: Let the bard have the corner by the stove; his songs make men forget to argue. Charge him half for the chair he broke. Full for the pie.

items.title: City Watch Note from Irenne
items.body: No brawls at the river stairs. Boys with sticks kept time and tempers. A noblewoman watched from the wall and smiled like a schoolmistress.

items.title: Canalmen’s Tide Rhyme
items.body:
When stone hums low and water’s slack,
Step easy, boys, and mind your back.
When wind comes round and flame takes air,
Sing soft, or trouble climbs the stair.

items.title: Abbey Kitchen Chit
items.body: Loaves to the copyists (4). Broth to the guest with the lute (1 bowl, refilled thrice). Salt to the gate (a pinch for the road).

items.title: Merchant Carta to a Partner, On Copies
items.body:
Giles—
They will not sell me the book, only trade leaf for leaf. I left them a shipping table and received a poem with numbers hiding in it. Profitable? Perhaps in a kinder world.
—C.

items.title: City Broadside: “Mind the Steps”
items.body: Citizens! Keep markets clear for measure at the second bell. Bring a stick; leave your quarrels. Lost tempers to be claimed at the watch-house.

items.title: Widow’s Candle-Note at the Chapel
items.body: For a husband who marched to drums and forgot to listen. For a son who learned to step and came home laughing.

items.title: Cartwright’s Axle Song
items.body: Grease speaks better than orders. If your wheel sings, listen; it tells you where the road is crooked.

items.title: Scrivener’s Market Minute
items.body: Noted: boys in wide steps by the fishmongers; quarrel settled at the third cut (no blood). A bard bought a lemon and a silence.

items.title: Stable Boy’s Practice in Straw
items.body: Master said mind the corners. The mare learned first; she steps wider than me.

items.title: Ferryman to His Brother, On a Quiet Oar
items.body: We pulled a noble and her maid across at dusk. She paid in silver and asked about the boys with sticks. I said they were learning to listen with their feet.

items.title: Seamstress to a Soldier’s Wife
items.body:
Marta—
The patch is strong where his jacket split. I stitched a little rest into the seam. Tell him to wear it where men shout.

items.title: Bellringer’s Noon Toll Note
items.body:
Second bell for drill. Third for bread. Fourth if the wind turns rough.
P.S. Do not let the drummer lead the boys; he forgets the rests.

items.title: FB → ML: The Quiet Sigil
items.body:
Master Lychenar,
I tried the new step you taught—the circle that closes like a book. Here, it closes too neatly; men in Maraisbourg notice neatness, and notice is a tax I cannot pay. Merryen holds court with Octish traders in the tannery loft. He calls it a fencing society; I hear the rustle of paper more than steel. Their talk is wind on stone. Mine is Silence on ink. I keep your sigil covered and speak when strings demand it.
If the fifth song is to be played, it will be by accident—like a chord struck by a drunk who somehow finds harmony. My cure is to keep the lute in its case.
—FB

items.title: From the Quays at Maraisbourg
items.body:
ML,
Barges from the north unloaded casks labeled VINEGAR that smell like ink. Printers wink as if winks were currency. I played a tavern set to muddy the room while a crate changed hands. The tune was cheerful enough that no one noticed the silence underneath it. You were right: songs are cloaks when worn correctly.
The Octs want a banner for their hills. Merryen wants a book for his throne. I want my supper hot and my conscience cool. Two of us will be disappointed.
—Faelar

items.title: Margin Note on the Wide Steps
items.body:
FB—
Keep the wide step wide; narrow steps are invitations to small mistakes with large funerals. If Merryen is dancing in print, step off the page. When a crowd claps, it is not for truth—it is for rhythm. We teach neither crowd nor clap. We teach men to walk away.
—ML

items.title: Chalk Dust and Copies
items.body:
Master,
A trader offered silver for the whole book again. I told him what I told the last man: a copy for a copy. He laughed and said that was priest-talk. I said no—printer-talk. He paid for the ale and left poorer.
If you find my tone casual, forgive me; the city teaches casual like the sea teaches damp. Still, I keep the pages dry. If a storm comes, I know which song not to sing.
—FB

items.title: Unscored Fragments (Not for the Stage)
items.body:
ML,
Three fragments arrived from Lynden with the corners burned and the measures missing. Whoever copied them knew enough to cut the parts where men start marching in straight lines. I hummed what was left. The room cooled. The Fifth is a winter even in summer.
I locked them behind the bread bin; thieves love jewels and forget flour.
—Faelar

items.title: A Letter of Not Playing
items.body:
Master,
There is a fashion here for loud courage. Men shout plans so the plans feel real. I played a soft air until their bravery remembered its wife and went home. Tomorrow I travel with canal men who fear only leaky barrels. I envy them; their gods are water and rope.
I remain, as always, your student in the art of not performing.
—FB

items.title: Seven Strings in Quiet
items.body:
Faelar,
You ask when to tune the seventh string. Never in public, seldom in private, and only when the room is so still you can hear ink drying. If you must strike it, strike it like an apology. Men who love banners will not understand what they have heard until it is too late.
Teach the young to fix roofs before they learn to knock doors.
—Lychenar

items.title: An Oath by the Canal
items.body:
ML,
A boy tried to swear himself to me tonight. I gave him a rope knot instead of a vow and told him to learn which way water wants to go. He laughed, then listened, then cried. I suppose that is the order of wisdom.
If the city burns for its gods, we will carry buckets until the fire remembers it is only a temper.
—FB

items.title: FB to ML
items.body:
Master,

The market bells here ring on time even when the men do not. Merryen smiles too brightly. He measures courtyards with his eyes as if they were parade grounds and says the north wind will bring friends who knot their maps instead of drawing them. He will not speak the name of Rowen’s city without spitting first; Lynden lives rent-free in his jaw. I nod, take notes that look like scales for a sad song, and keep my counsel.

The Free Cities talk louder than they listen. In the guild we have not forgotten our fifth. We name it only as a folded page. We play Wind, Stone, Flame, and Water in the open, but the last we keep under the bridge of the lute, where the sound is felt and not heard. I can hear its tread in the courtyards—counting, counting. You taught me to hear it and then to put it away.

Once a trader offered silver for the whole manuscript-in-progress. I closed the cover and pushed it back to him. “You can have a copy,” I said, “if you leave a copy behind.” He left a page he did not understand and took away a page he never will. The bargain holds: knowledge breeds only when it travels both ways.

I confess a weariness. Every tool finds a hand; even wrapped in cloth, a blade teaches the fingers by shape alone. The fifth is a stair and fools will climb it just to see who salutes. So I write the steps into chords and waystones, and I sing them wrong when company gathers. Let the wrong ears remember the wrong tune.

If you would have me leave this city, write a single dot under the third line of your reply. If not, I will linger and practice the long measure at dusk until the drilling drowns it. The stone by the river hums at the turn of tide. Either the gods are listening, or men are.

Your student in poor spirits and plain ink,
FB

items.title: From the Scriptorium
items.body:
To the Prior at St. Eber,
The chest you sent contained three leaves under a merchant’s accounts. Two bear the same hand as the so-called Maros diagrams, though the ink is poorer. We copy by night. Tell the men with torches to find another door.

items.title: A Soldier’s Letter Home
items.body:
Marta—
The little one coughs? Keep her by the hearth. We march slow; the Duke’s men argue more than they drill. I saw a man cross blades without anger—he sang under his breath. If I come home, I’ll ask him to teach me that.

items.title: Apprentice to His Mother
items.body:
Mother,
The master hides his formes in flour sacks. If soldiers come, I am to spill the meal and sneeze until they laugh. I press letters by day and copy by night. My fingers are black, but my heart is clean.

items.title: Quartermaster’s Memo
items.body:
To Captain Vess:
Salt short. Vinegar gone. Men cut with rust for want of oil. Request wagon from East Gate. If refused, purchase from canal men at double. The Duke prefers speed to thrift.

items.title: Entry from the Westward Trader
items.body: Fifth day without fresh water. Three down with fever. A passenger set the men to drilling with ropes for blades; spirits steadier after. If we see a green coast by week’s end, I’ll name him our lucky star.

items.title: Minute of the Red Canal Guild
items.body:
Item: The vote stands at six for silence, three for appeal.
Item: Concerning the printer of Maraisbourg—keep his name from the rolls.
Item: The hand that stirs the ink must not stir the city.

items.title: Memorandum to the Council
items.body: The art is best kept in open halls, where its music tames young blood. Close the doors, and Flame finds its own teachers. I, as surety, offer my seal that Lutefecht will not mint soldiers.

items.title: Extract of an Imperial Edict
items.body: Let no man sell manuals of war without patent or priestly witness. Those who keep schools must post their names. Those who keep secrets must answer for them.

items.title: Lynden Dockmaster’s Report
items.body:
To the Harbor Warden:
Storm wreckage came in with the morning tide. One man clung to a plank, half-frozen, carrying a journal in oilcloth. Says little, watches much.

items.title: Admonition to a Young Scribe
items.body: Ink is mercy when fire is law. Copy the verses, but leave breath between the lines. A book without rests is a drum for marching.

items.title: A Gloss in the Margin (unsigned)
items.body: Four sing, the fifth listens. When a city forgets the fifth, the song becomes a march. Leave rests upon the bar or the bar will break. —L.

items.title: A Minstrel’s Note to His Companion
items.body:
Tara—
The tavern in Drossel burned last night. I saved my lute, though not the case. The crowd sang while the rafters fell. I think the gods prefer a melody with danger in its chorus.

items.title: Scribe’s Field Report
items.body:
To the Archivist of Meyren:
The field copyists have begun carving words into their shields. They say it helps recall stances. One wrote ‘Patience’ upon his guard, and the enemy broke his rhythm reading it.

items.title: Invitation from the Duchess of Irenne
items.body:
To Master of Songs and Blades,
Attend upon our hall this midsummer eve. Bring not your steel, but bring your verses. The court would learn how men once fought with grace, not noise.

items.title: The Hermit’s Last Page
items.body: I burned the book today. Not for heresy, but for warmth. The snow took my ink, the cold my will. If any find this ash, know that truth was written once, between parries, and that it sang.

items.title: Smith’s Ledger Margin
items.body: Note: The third hammer-swing hums truer if struck to the rhythm of the March of Bonona. Apprentice to sing as he works—steel remembers music better than words.

items.title: Librarian’s Warning to the Master of Pages
items.body: Seal the lower stacks. The diagrams breathe when wet. The last reader forgot to close the clasp and the ink crawled across his palm. We keep him writing, for now.

items.title: Fragment from a Seer’s Journal
items.body: They will build an Empire of rhythm and call it peace. When every man moves in time, none will hear the off-beat. My task is not to sing—but to cough.

items.title: Unsent Edict Found in the Emperor’s Desk
items.body: Let it be written that no blade shall sing unless tuned by the hand of law. Let it be whispered that music itself may rebel.

items.title: A Soldier’s Letter Home
items.body:
Marta—
The little one coughs? Keep her by the hearth. We march slow; the Duke’s men argue more than they drill. I saw a man cross blades without anger—he sang under his breath. If I come home, I’ll ask him to teach me that.

items.title: Apprentice to His Mother
items.body:
Mother,
The master hides his formes in flour sacks. If soldiers come, I am to spill the meal and sneeze until they laugh. I press letters by day and copy by night. My fingers are black, but my heart is clean.

items.title: Quartermaster’s Memo
items.body:
To Captain Vess:
Salt short. Vinegar gone. Men cut with rust for want of oil. Request wagon from East Gate. If refused, purchase from canal men at double. The Duke prefers speed to thrift.

items.title: Tavern Chit, Unpaid
items.body:
— 3 ales (thin)
— 1 pie (mysterious)
— 1 chair (broken, by singer)
Note: The singer promised to pay in a rousing chorus. The chorus was rousing. The payment was theoretical.

items.title: Oct Scout’s Tie-Mark
items.body: Birch peeled at the north bend. Three knots—safe water; one cut—watch the wind. We saw beacon smoke on the western headland. The stone there hums when the tide turns.

items.title: Handbill from Maraisbourg
items.body: Citizens! Stand tall and learn the long measure! A people well-footed need no masters. Drill at dawn by the river stairs. Bring a stick; leave with a step.

items.title: Guild Note to Lynden
items.body:
To Master Rowen of Lynden,
Your last parcel arrived damp and argumentative. The diagrams, however, sang sense once dried. We decline your invitation to instruct your Duke’s levy. Our music is for roads, not thrones.

items.title: Copyist’s Bargain
items.body:
Sir,
You may have a copy, if you leave a copy behind. This is the treaty of the road: knowledge breeds when it is not locked up like a hound. Leave a pup; take a pup.

items.title: Lychenar’s Marginalia (Folded Twice)
items.body:
Four are sung.
The fifth is kept.
If you must choose a god, choose the one that listens.
—L.

items.title: Unmailed Letter from Captain Vess
items.body:
To be opened by the Boatswain, or, failing him, by any man who still knows the taste of tar and wind,

Aboard the Everspring,
three leagues west of the Iron Shoals

Bosun—

You may think me drunk on sour rum or sunstroke, but I’ll swear this by the mizzenmast’s own creak: the stowaway was a blessing. Found him coiled among the sailcloth like a cat, thin as rope’s end and twice as frayed, clutching a lute as if it were scripture. I’d have had him whipped to the gunwale for hiding, but the tide was foul and the wind colder than law, so I kept him on to swab the deck. By second bell he’d made the planks shine, and by sunset he’d taught half the crew how to step to measure.

Calls himself Faelar Brighton, a bard by trade, though I’ve seen few bards who keep such measure in the midst of a gale. When we were becalmed near the Shoals, he drew a star on the deck between main and mizzen—five points, broad and perfect—and began to teach the crew footwork as though he’d a school instead of a ship. I meant to have it holystoned off, but the men fought better for it, so I let it be.

Come next dawn, raiders rose out of the fog—black sails, no colours shown. Faelar took the quarterdeck without leave and called the crew to measure. They fought not as killers but as craftsmen. The star on the deck became a compass, and the Everspring herself sang through the smoke.

That night, when all was done and our dead counted, he and I shared what little rum remained. He spoke of guilds where art and mercy were brothered, and I—fool that I am—believed we might found one of our own. “A seaward chapter,” I told him, “to teach measure before men learn blood.” He smiled and said the sea was too wide for a single compass, but his eyes said hope otherwise.

Now the wind’s turned. Rations thin, casks lighter than they should be, and the hands whisper mutiny. They say I spare faith for a bard and none for sailors. They forget that the Everspring’s name was meant as a promise—new beginnings for us all. But promises rot faster than rope in damp hold.

If this reaches you, Bosun, tell Faelar that Captain Vess forgave the sea before it took him. Tell him the measure holds, even when the ship heels. Tell him to build the Guild on land, where no tide can claim it.

I can hear them now on the ladderway. The mizzen groans like a soul that knows its end.

— Captain T. Vess
Master and Commander, Everspring
Westward Trader Line, in faith to no crown but the compass
